title: Sky Storage Download Feature
body:
Add a Sky Storage Download Feature. Also fixes #932.

To download a folder from a bucket using Sky Storage, run:
```
from sky.data import storage, StoreType
storage_obj = storage.Storage(name='imagenet-bucket')
storage_obj.add_store(StoreType.S3)
storage_obj.download('~/Downloads/hello')
```
(also works for GCS)

## Tests
- [x] Code above for both S3 and GCS

title: Fix Storage Download to Local
body:
Now Sky Storage advanced python users can download a bucket to local.

## Tests

```
from sky.data import storage, StoreType
storage_obj = storage.Storage(name='imagenet-bucket')
storage_obj.add_store(StoreType.S3)
s3_store =storage_obj.stores[StoreType.S3]
s3_store.download_remote_dir('~/Downloads/hello')
```

title: fix schema check for sky spot
body:
This PR fixes a schema check bug which incorrectly errors out when the below YAML syntax is used.
```
accelerator:
  V100: 1
```
Sky Spot also uses this syntax to generate YAML and it'd break silently with showing the job to be "PENDING" forever.
Also changes `resnet_app.yaml` to this syntax to catch such bugs in smoke tests.

title: Documents for using TPU node and TPU VM
body: It would be great to have a tutorial in our document for using TPU nodes and TPU VMs in our document. Currently, we only have a single line in the YAML spec, which may not be enough to show how to use it.

title: Update error message for unknown YAML fields
body:
As discussed in #674, this updates the default error message when unknown fields are encountered in the YAML schema to be clearer, building on #926. Please feel free to raise any nits on how to improve the message.

Previously:
```
❯ sky launch -c mycluster hello_sky.yaml --docker
Task from YAML spec: hello_sky.yaml
ValueError: Invalid resources YAML: Additional properties are not allowed ('spot_recovery1' was unexpected)
Instead of spot_recovery1, did you mean spot_recovery?
```

Now:
```
❯ sky launch -c mycluster hello_sky.yaml --docker
Task from YAML spec: hello_sky.yaml
ValueError: Invalid resources YAML: The following fields are invalid:
Instead of 'spot_recovery1', did you mean 'spot_recovery'?
```

Tested:
- [Full configuration](https://sky-proj-sky.readthedocs-hosted.com/en/latest/reference/yaml-spec.html)
- Failing enum checks
- Failing type checks
- Unknown fields

title: Enable custom image for AWS and GCP
body:
Closes #683.

This PR enables the user to specify their own image when launching a cluster.
```
# test_ami.yaml
resources:
  cloud: aws
  region: us-east-1
  image_id: ami-0f17aadac8db87c56
setup:
  echo "running setup"

run: |
  echo 'hello sky'
```
```
# test_ami_gcp.yaml
resources:
  cloud: gcp
  image_id: projects/ubuntu-os-pro-cloud/global/images/family/ubuntu-pro-1804-lts
setup:
  echo "running setup"

run: |
  echo 'hello sky'
```

The current implementation has some limitations:
1. It only supports AWS for now.
2. The user has to manually specify the cloud and region when the `image_id` is provided.
3. The image used for launching the instances may need to be debian-based, ~~and have pip3 installed.~~

TODOs:
- [x] Support GCP
- [x] Add doc

Future TODOs:
- Support Azure

Tested:
- [x] `sky launch -c test-ami test_ami.yaml`
- [x] `sky launch -c test-ami test_ami.yaml` again with a different AMI and it fails as expected for resource not match.
- [x] `sky launch -c test-ami-gcp test_ami_gcp.yaml`.
- [x] `sky launch -c nvidia-ami nvidia-ami.yaml`
  ```
  # nvidia-ami.yaml
  resources:
    cloud: aws
    region: us-east-1
    image_id: ami-0b0bae438f4bea93f
    accelerators: V100
  setup: |
    echo "running setup"
  
  run: |
    echo 'hello sky'
  ```

title: Enhance YAML schema validation
body:
Fixes #674.

Currently, the YAML schema validation only throws errors for unknown fields. It does not have support for required / optional fields, enum checks and type checks. 

I propose using the [JSON Schema](https://json-schema.org/) format to define and validate schemas for the YAML configuration file.  Although there are a number of mature Python libraries for data validation ([schema](https://github.com/keleshev/schema), [pydantic](https://pydantic-docs.helpmanual.io/), [ceberus](https://docs.python-cerberus.org/en/stable/) etc.), the main benefit of using JSON Schema is that it is an open specification and so we are not bound to any one implementation.

This PR replaces the current YAML validation with a validation based on JSON Schema that allows for handling unknown fields, enum checks, type checks and potentially a lot more complex validation as required. Similar to the current implementation, it also suggests the most similar field when an unknown field is encountered.

Tested:
- [Full configuration](https://sky-proj-sky.readthedocs-hosted.com/en/latest/reference/yaml-spec.html)
- Failing enum checks (e.g. `cloud: gcs` instead of `cloud: gcp` )
- Failing type checks (e.g. `num_nodes: one` instead of `num_nodes: 1`)
- Unknown fields (e.g. `num_workers` instead of `num_nodes`)

From what I see from the docs, there are no required fields so the schema does not specify any.

title: Add launch hash for refreshing and fix last_use
body:
Closes #922, and #924.

Main changes:
1. Match the cluster with ray launch hash as well to distinguish the clusters.
2. Do not update `last_use` and `launched_at` when refreshing
3. Add warning info for terminated clusters.

Tested:
- [x] `sky status -r`, the `last_use` column does not change for the UP cluster.
- [x] `sky launch -c gcp-start-stop --num-nodes 2 --cloud gcp ''`. Sky now can distinguish the cluster from this launch and the existing clusters with the same name on the UI. After stopping both head and worker node through UI, `sky status -r` shows STOPPED for the cluster.
- [x] `sky launch -c test-aws-launch-hash --num-nodes 2 ''` and `sky status -r` get the correct launch hash.
- [x] `sky launch -c test-azure-launch-hash --num-nodes 2 --cloud azure ''` and `sky status -r` get the correct launch hash.

title: UX: `last_use` column set to `sky status -r` after refreshing when the cluster is UP
[Discussion] Complete cluster status refresh before any internal operator
body:
For many internal operators, we will call the `refresh_cluster_status_handle` to get the actual status of the cluster to fail early. Currently, we only apply the actual refresh when the `autostop` is set. We should consider whether to check the real status for the cluster whatever the original status was. 

Personally, I would prefer to not check the real status for the cluster with no `autostop` set, since that will introduce not much benefit but large overheads.

title: Distinguish the clusters with the same `ray-cluster-name` tag when refreshing status
body: In #911, we assume that nodes with the same `ray-cluster-name` tag are in the same cluster, but when it comes to GCP or Azure, it is possible that the nodes with the same `ray-cluster-name` tag can be from different clusters with different resources created by different users. We may want to distinguish the clusters by considering the `ray-launch-config` (the hash for the config) as well.

title: Review and document slash `/` semantics for file_mounts and workdir
body:
Our handling of slashes seems different from `rsync`, which is surprising.  Doing a quick search in docs, I can't find any wording related to that handling.

```
workdir: dir/
```
* Expected: remote `~/sky_workdir/x` should exist for `dir/x` (rsync semantics)
* Actual: remote `~/sky_workdir/dir` exists

title: Using git repo in rsync file_mounts fails if not run in repo root
body:
If the file_mount source is a git repo, then running the sky YAML from anywhere but the root of the repo fails.

This is likely because our `--exclude-from` [flag to rsync](https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/blob/47be65aa1b6d505e9263e9935f15e36a6ff8666a/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L2440) has a relative path to `.git/info/exclude`.

# Example

Consider a YAML I created `tests/sky_smoke_tests.yaml`:
```
file_mounts:
  /sky_repo: /mnt/d/Romil/Berkeley/Research/sky-experiments

run: |
  echo hi
```

Here `sky-experiments` is root of our sky repo. If I try to run this YAML from the `tests` dir, it fails:

```

rsync: failed to open exclude file .git/info/exclude: No such file or directory (2)
rsync error: error in file IO (code 11) at exclude.c(1178) [client=3.1.2]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/mnt/d/Romil/Berkeley/Research/sky-experiments/sky/execution.py", line 153, in _execute
```

title: Mount mode support for GCS
body:
This PR adds support for FUSE mounting GCS using gcsfuse. 

* Updated `examples/storage/pingpong.yaml` to use gcs.
* We need to update the optimizer to automatically pick the right backing store if `store` is not specified in the Storage YAML. That's a bigger effort (how do we pick which backing store to use? do we migrate if required?) and probably a separate PR.
* Functionally gcsfuse seems okay. At a cursory glance the performance seems comparable to goofys, but we need to formally benchmark this. gcsfuse also very likely suffers from similar [OOM issues](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/gcsfuse/issues/679) as goofys.

Closes #915.

- [x] `pytest test_smoke.py::TestStorageWithCredentials`

title: Race Condition for Sky Storage
body: Replication: Run `sky launch -c hello storage.yaml` with a filemount, while the Storage object is syncing, run `sky storage delete ...`

title: Race condition for ssh config file
body: During the discussion with @concretevitamin, we found a race condition for the ssh config file modification in our code. If two threads read the config for modifying config for the clusters, there can be a race condition, since one thread can overwrite the modification of another thread.

title: Refresh the cluster status with the cloud CLI
body:
Partially fixes #904.
This PR is the first step for using cloud CLI tools to fetch the cluster status. Although I implemented the status fetching for all the nodes in clusters, I am trying to be conservative in this PR, without letting the cluster status always up-to-date. Here are several reasons:
1. We do not want to set the cluster to UP, even if the CLI tells us all the nodes in the cluster are running, since the ray cluster may not be correctly set yet, i.e. the cluster should be in INIT status.
1. We need to deal with the status transition of the clusters, e.g. `sky launch` will transit the cluster status from `None` to `INIT` and then to `UP`, or `sky stop` will transit the cluster status from `UP` to `STOPPED`. If we update the status too frequently, there will be race conditions. For example:
  a. `sky launch` adds the INIT status in the DB, `ray up` has not started the instance yet.
  b. user call `sky status -r`: sky finds the cluster_name does not exist and removes the entry for that cluster from the database.
  c. `sky launch` is interrupted by the user, when the node is already launched, but not ready, so no new entries are written back to the database.
  d. Then there is a resource leakage since the cluster is removed from the database, but the node has been launched.
1. The case for multi-node clusters is very complicated, as we need to distinguish whether the cluster is partly terminated by the user manually through the UI, is auto-stopping, or is in the middle of launching.
1. For the spot cluster, we may want to set the spot cluster to STOPPED, to avoid confusing the user with why their cluster disappeared. Stopping after preemption is the default behavior for GCP and Azure, but AWS does not support stopping the spot instance when preemption happens (only supported when the spot request is persistent, i.e. keeps trying automatically after preempted).

Main changes:
1. Added functions for updating fetching the real cluster status using the cloud-specific CLIs.
1. Handle the edge case where the user manually stops or terminates the cluster in the cloud UI, as mentioned in #904.

Tested:
```
NAME                  LAUNCHED     RESOURCES                  STATUS   AUTOSTOP  COMMAND                             
test-fetch-state-gcp  10 hrs ago   2x GCP(n1-highmem-8)       UP       -         sky launch --num-nodes 2 -c ...     
test-fetch-state      9 hrs ago    2x AWS(m6i.2xlarge)        UP       0 min     sky launch --num-nodes 2 -c ...     
sky-cpunode-zhwu      3 hrs ago    1x AWS(m6i.2xlarge)        STOPPED  -         sky cpunode                         
sky-e895-zhwu         10 mins ago  1x AWS(m6i.2xlarge[Spot])  UP       -         sky launch --use-spot --cloud aws  
```
Using `sky status -r` takes 7.3 sconds.
```
NAME                  LAUNCHED     RESOURCES                  STATUS   AUTOSTOP  COMMAND                             
test-fetch-state-gcp  10 hrs ago   2x GCP(n1-highmem-8)       UP       -         sky launch --num-nodes 2 -c ...     
test-fetch-state      9 hrs ago    2x AWS(m6i.2xlarge)        STOPPED  0 min     sky launch --num-nodes 2 -c ...     
sky-cpunode-zhwu      3 hrs ago    1x AWS(m6i.2xlarge)        STOPPED  -         sky cpunode
```

title: Launching Azure cluster with more than 2 nodes fails
body:
When launching the azure cluster with more than 2 nodes with `sky launch --cloud azure --num-nodes 2 ''`, we observed the following error, where ray fails to launch the second node. It seems to be a problem with the credentials uploaded to the cluster, but I am able to launch azure instance with the uploaded credentials.
https://gist.github.com/concretevitamin/f4a5fadb5a7b7d8fd56770133898e111

title: TPU: investigate whether on-demand TPUs get killed occasionally
body:
A TPU user mentioned that for TPUs, even with on-demand TPU, it will be killed at any time within every 2 days, and no logs can be found for the reason. Quote: "Before deadline, I have to get up in the midnight to see if my job being killed, due to the failure of TPU. It would be good thing to look at for the spot feature."

We should first investigate this issue (e.g., low cost `sky tpunode --tpus tpu-v2-8`) and see how we can solve this problem.

title: UX: remove `ray-` in cluster node names
body:
Mentioned by Ritwik during onboarding.  Slight confusion.  He preferred that if a cluster is named "mycluster", then it's easier to see in the console the nodes being named "mycluster-{head,...}" without prefix.

We could patch related files in Ray autoscaler.  I filed https://github.com/ray-project/ray/issues/20944 before which includes the files we need to patch -- it's unlikely the Ray team would make the naming format configurable.

title: UX: make `sky status` refresh correctly and by default
body:
From Ritwik's onborading: "it’s counter-intuitive to me `sky status` doesn’t refresh by default."

We can make it refresh correctly by talking with the cloud provider. Currently refresh simply pings - if a cluster is unreachable, it's considered STOPPED but it could have been terminated manually.

We can make it refresh by default without the need to remember typing `-r`.

title: [Docker] Docker backend creates two clusters in `global_user_state`
body:
On launching a task with `--docker`, I am seeing sky create two cluster entries - `mytask` and `skydocker-mytask`:

```
(base) romilb@romilbx1yoga:/mnt/d/Romil/Berkeley/Research/sky-experiments/examples/$ sky launch -c mytask minimal.yaml --docker
Task from YAML spec: minimal.yaml
Launching a new cluster 'mytask'. Proceed? [Y/n]: Y
Running task on cluster mytask...
I 06-02 21:37:33 local_docker_backend.py:167] Streaming build logs is not supported in LocalDockerBackend. Build logs will be shown on failure.
I 06-02 21:37:33 local_docker_backend.py:170] Building docker image for task minimal. This might take some time.
I 06-02 21:37:33 docker_utils.py:174] Using tempdir /tmp/sky_local_t_ea4ini for docker build.
I 06-02 21:37:35 local_docker_backend.py:175] Image minimal built.
I 06-02 21:37:35 local_docker_backend.py:176] Provisioning complete.
I 06-02 21:37:35 local_docker_backend.py:230] Image minimal found. Running container now. use_gpu is False
I 06-02 21:37:36 local_docker_backend.py:263] Your container is now running with name: skydocker-mytask.
I 06-02 21:37:36 local_docker_backend.py:263] To get a shell in your container, run: docker exec -it skydocker-mytask /bin/bash.
I 06-02 21:37:36 local_docker_backend.py:263] You can debug the image by running: docker run -it minimal /bin/bash.
I 06-02 21:37:36 local_docker_backend.py:263]
I 06-02 21:37:41 local_docker_backend.py:320] # conda environments:
I 06-02 21:37:41 local_docker_backend.py:320] #
I 06-02 21:37:41 local_docker_backend.py:320] base                  *  /opt/conda
I 06-02 21:37:41 local_docker_backend.py:342] Your container is now running with name skydocker-mytask
I 06-02 21:37:41 local_docker_backend.py:345] To get a shell in your container, run docker exec -it skydocker-mytask /bin/bash
I 06-02 21:37:41 local_docker_backend.py:351] To create a new container for debugging without running the task run command, run docker run -it minimal:latest /bin/bash
NAME              LAUNCHED        RESOURCES  STATUS  AUTOSTOP  COMMAND                                   
mytask            a few secs ago  docker     INIT    -         sky launch -c mytask ../minimal.yaml ...
skydocker-mytask  a few secs ago  docker     UP      -         sky launch -c mytask ../minimal.yaml ...
```

`sky down mytask` succeeds and `skydocker-mytask` gets removed and the container is deleted, but `mytask` remains in the global_user_state.

This was likely introduced in #842 which changed the call `global_user_state.get_cluster_name_from_handle` to `handle.get_cluster_name`. Since `handle.get_cluster_name` doesn't lstrip the sky prefix, it creates a new entry in global_user_state when it calls `add_or_update_cluster` after setup is complete.

title: [Job] Pending Jobs Hanging
body:
Suppose the user launches a cluster of 4 V100 and submits two jobs with 2 V100s.  The cluster is now full.

Submitting a 3rd job with 2 V100s will be placed as PENDING for the Ray autoscaler. However, `sky launch -c asdf job.yaml` will hang, since the job is waiting for other two jobs to finish.

title: Storage delete no local folder fix
body:
Fixes #855. The bug was in `_validate_source` where Sky Storage detects `source` doesn't exist and errors out. To fix this, Sky Storage will not check if `source` exists if `sync_on_reconstruction` is False.

## Tests

Task YAML
```
file_mounts:
  /checkpoints:
    name: michaels-new-bucket-1
    source: ~/Downloads/hallo
    store: gcs
    mode: COPY
```

`mv ~/Downloads/hallo ~/Downloads/hello`
`sky storage delete michaels-new-bucket-1`

For the second command, AWS is shown to be chosen, but then we are actually reconnecting to the existing Azure node (see last 3 lines).

---- 

This seems to relate to the reuse logic of interactive nodes.  @Michaelvll and I discussed about simplifying the logic as follows:
> throw an error if (1) -c or an implied -c points to an existing cluster; & (2) any resource args are supplied.

Also see https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/pull/859#issuecomment-1142417700.

title: Storage Delete for GCP >= 256 Objects
body:
Fixes #724. Now, GCP storage code will detect if the bucket has >=256 objects. If there are more than 256 objects, then it will delete the contents in the bucket first.

## Tests

`touch ~/Downloads/hallo/{0001..0258}.c` 

YAML file
```
file_mounts:
  /checkpoints:
    name: michaels-new-bucket-1
    source: ~/Downloads/hallo
    store: gcs
    mode: COPY
```

`sky launch -c hallo storage.yaml && sky storage delete michaels-new-bucket-1`

title: Autocompletion for the CLI using tab
body: It would be great if we can using `tab` to auto-complete the cluster name when typing the CLI commands. I tried to implement that in [cluster-auto-complete](https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/tree/cluster-auto-complete), but the auto-completion is very laggy at that time.

title: Support regions outside US
body: We need to support regions outside the US, and have a way to configure what regions to try on. [faster-retry-switch](https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/tree/faster-retry-switch) has the code for adding this.

title: Protobuf version conflicts
body:
Fixes https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/879 by enforcing the protobuf version to be < 4.0.0.
Ray has recently done the same fix but it will be available later in 1.13.
https://github.com/ray-project/ray/pull/25211/files

- [x] Test on my macbook.
- ~~[x] Add a new workflow test for using conda to install sky. Hopefully this would catch errors early on in the future.~~

title: Fix Storage Creation
body:
Fixes #796. This should work 100% of the time now (syncing from creating a new bucket).

The bug is that, sometimes, even if the bucket does not exists, `s3.meta.client` call does not error found, so the code thinks that the bucket exists. (https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/blob/master/sky/data/storage.py#L799).

The solution was hence to replace the existing logic of bucket creation.


## Tests

- [x] `sky storage delete michaels-new-bucket-[ID] && sky launch -c hi storage.yaml` many times

title: Remove azureTokens.json from the credential list
body:
Thanks to @concretevitamin and @romilb for finding and identifying this problem. With my `azure-core` cli (version `2.30.0`), there will be no `azureTokens.json` generated in the credential folder.  We should remove the file from the folder to avoid ray file_mounts failure.

Tested:
- [x] `sky cpunode --cloud azure` and `sky cpunode -c remote-cpunode --cloud azure` on the remote instance.

title: Fix recursive symlinks when uploading to sky storage

Closes #814 by using `--no-follow-symlinks` flag for `aws s3 sync`. Sky Storage now ignores all symlinks (like regular file_mounts, I believe).

Tested:
- [x] `./tests/run_smoke_tests.sh test_file_mounts`
- [x] `pytest test_smoke.py::TestStorageWithCredentials`

The bigger problem is our default image provider, `gpuci`, has stopped updating the `gpuci/miniconda-cuda:11.4-runtime-ubuntu18.04` image ([see jenkins](https://gpuci.io/job/gpuci/job/docker/job/miniconda-cuda/)). A fix is to switch to `gpuci/miniforge-cuda` family of images.

title: Move the functionality of cli to sdk
body: We need to move the functionality of the current CLI to SDK so that we can align the CLI and programmatic APIs. One example of the benefit is we can replace the `subprocess` call of the CLI commands with SDK, e.g. `subprocess.run('sky status')` in the cloud_vm_ray_backend.

title: Make the spot job pending as soon as the job is submitted
body: Closes #865. Otherwise, if the running spot job is more than 16, the submitted job will not be in `sky spot status` unless a running spot job finishes. This PR is blocked by #862. Tested: - [x] `for i in $(seq 20); do sky spot launch -n test-pending-$i 'echo started; sleep 12000; echo ended' -y &; done; wait` will have the following output. PS: The number of the total in-progress jobs does not equal 20 because some `rsync` fails due to the parallel ssh problem, raised by @suquark before.

title: Sky docker image
body:
# What is this
This PR adds a Dockerfile for the sky cli tool and adds a pointer to a built image that users can easily run on their laptops.

# Why do we need this
During our onboarding sessions, we spend 15 min+ installing sky on users' laptops, and they often run into env specific issues which take up a lot of time when we are simply trying to demo sky to them.

If users already have docker, they can simply run this prebuilt docker image. It contains all aws, gcloud and azure dependencies installed and sky ready to go.

We can pull and run this docker image in `1min 41s` (on m5.xlarge) and requires zero changes to user's env if they have docker installed.

This is not a replacement for installing sky, this is simply for demoing sky.

# How do users use this

If users just want to test drive sky, they can simply run 

```
docker run -td --name sky --rm public.ecr.aws/a9w6z7w5/sky:latest
docker exec -it sky /bin/bash
```

Then they can run `aws configure` or `gcloud init` or `az login` and they should be able to use sky. 

# Open questions

* The currently added link is a public docker image. Anyone can pull it provided they have the URL. This is good and bad. Good because we can easily share sky for people to test drive. Bad because anyone with the link can access it.

* How do we keep the built image updated to master? Can we add a github action? Right now I have built and pushed it manually.

title: Fix sqlite3 rename problem with older version
body:
When we are trying to set up sky on Fabio's laptop with python virtenv, and found the `sky check` complains about renaming the column in the state.db.

After debugging with @infwinston , we found that the problem is caused by an older version of sqlite3 (<3.25) which does not support the syntax for renaming columns.

We remove the usage of the rename function since all our users should already be on our relatively new version of sky (within 2 months). It should be safe to use the new column name without the renaming.

title: UX: are confirmation prompts needed?
body:
From Daniel
>It's been a little while now, and the confirmation prompts have not grown on me. I think a confirmation prompt makes sense when you run a command and you're not exactly sure what's going to happen (e.g. with conda install, where it might decide to downgrade some package in order to install the one you asked for). **I don't think they make sense** when the sole purpose of the prompt is "are you sure you want to do literally the thing you just typed?". **The prompts are annoying** because sometimes I forget -y in scripts that run sky commands, and sometimes I run sky launch without -y and then immediately switch to a new window, and when I come back 5 minutes later it's still waiting for me to press enter

> I think the only command where a prompt could be justified is sky down since it deletes data. But even then, I think there's a reason why there's no "are you sure?" prompt even if you run rm -rf /. But for other commands (especially sky stop, sky start, sky autostop) **I don't understand the motivation at all**, since these commands are usually entirely reversible. Maybe a prompt if you sky stop a cluster that has running jobs?

Emphases mine.

---

Initial thought:

The original motivation was to avoid accidental launches, which cost $$$.  For example `terraform apply` will show
```
...
Plan: 128 to add, 0 to change, 0 to destroy.

Do you want to perform these actions?
  Terraform will perform the actions described above.
  Only 'yes' will be accepted to approve.

  Enter a value:
```

I think the best thing to do is to use this issue to collect votes from non-dev users and act on that.

title: UX: add "wait until launched" option to `sky launch`
body:
Currently, both @Michaelvll and Daniel have used/discussed using wrapping `sky launch` in a bash loop in case launching fails.  They used something like
```
 until sky launch ...; do; done
```
to manually make this work.  We should consider adding a `--wait-until-up / -w` or  `--retry-until-up / -r` option.

title: Cache head node ip address
body:
The original code tried to reuse a cached head node ip address, but this does not actually work well when multiple processes are accessing the same node. Also the reusing could be dangerous because the head node may already down, so the ip address is actually invalid, and it is not checked in `get_node_ips`.

This PR stores the head node ip address in the database in the right place (so multiple processes can share it once the head node ip is updated), and it performs a quick check of the aliveness of the head node when getting cached IP.

title: Fix unnecessary ssh hanging issue on Ray
body:
This PR aims to fix https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/849 by patching Ray autoscaler. Detailed explained in the issue.

We think a simple way is to patch Ray's autoscaler by adding

`self.provider.non_terminated_nodes({})`
before https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/6d978ab10ec65da1018790f8605b5b8946e838e5/python/ray/autoscaler/_private/updater.py#L272.

`non_terminated_nodes()` will refresh the states of `self.cached_nodes` and then ray will be able to detect whether the VM is terminated during ssh retry.

----

Regarding testing this PR, unfortunately https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/849 is a little bit hard to reproduce. I tried to manually terminate the VM but this way there won't be gap between VM shutting down and VM state being RUNNING. Not sure if we can simulate preemption signals.

title: Unnecessary 15+ mins is spent on Ray ssh attempts to a dead VM on GCP during spot recovery
body:
I've seen multiple times that Ray autoscaler wasting 15+mins during spot recovery on ssh login to a dead VM on GCP.
This brings a significant delay for spot recovery (from 15mins to 30mins).

The reason is Ray wrongly assumed the VM is still alive.

According to https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instances/preemptible#preemption-process
```
Compute Engine performs the following steps to preempt an instance:

1. Compute Engine sends a preemption notice to the instance in the form of an ACPI G2 Soft Off signal. You can use a shutdown script to handle the preemption notice and complete cleanup actions before the instance stops.
2. If the instance does not stop after 30 seconds, Compute Engine sends an ACPI G3 Mechanical Off signal to the operating system.
3. Compute Engine transitions the instance to a TERMINATED state.
```

However, there is a significant time gap (~1 min, observed empirically) between step 2 and 3. Hence ray autoscaler wrongly thought that the VM is still in RUNNING state and tried to ssh login. It kept trying for 15mins and failed.
```
ssh: connect to host 35.222.69.89 port 22: Connection timed out                                                                                                                             ssh: connect to host 35.222.69.89 port 22: Connection timed out                                                                                                                             
ssh: connect to host 35.222.69.89 port 22: Connection timed out                                                                   
ssh: connect to host 35.222.69.89 port 22: Connection timed out                                                                                                                             
ssh: connect to host 35.222.69.89 port 22: Connection timed out                                                                                                                             ssh: connect to host 35.222.69.89 port 22: Connection timed out                                                                                                                             Exception in thread Thread-1:                                                                                                                                                               
Traceback (most recent call last):                                                                                                
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.9/threading.py", line 954, in _bootstrap_inner                                                                                                               
    self.run()                                                                                                                                                                                File "/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/ray/autoscaler/_private/updater.py", line 134, in run                                                                                   self.do_update()                                                                                                                                                                        
  File "/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/ray/autoscaler/_private/updater.py", line 299, in do_update               
    self.wait_ready(deadline)                                                                                                                                                               
  File "/home/ubuntu/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/ray/autoscaler/_private/updater.py", line 248, in wait_ready                                                                            raise Exception("wait_ready timeout exceeded.")                                                                                                                                         Exception: wait_ready timeout exceeded.                                                                                                                                                     
2022-05-16 22:22:04,680 PANIC commands.py:724 -- Failed to setup head node.                                                       
Error: Failed to setup head node.  
```

In fact Autoscaler already implemented similar logic [here](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/6d978ab10ec65da1018790f8605b5b8946e838e5/python/ray/autoscaler/_private/updater.py#L272) to detect vm states before each ssh attempts. However, the VM states they used to check is cached (code [here](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/master/python/ray/autoscaler/_private/gcp/node_provider.py#L124)) and can be out-to-date. They do not refresh VM's states by calling GCP's API.

I discussed with @Michaelvll about possible solutions. We think a simple way is to patch Ray's autoscaler by adding 
```
self.provider.non_terminated_nodes({})
```
before https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/6d978ab10ec65da1018790f8605b5b8946e838e5/python/ray/autoscaler/_private/updater.py#L272.

`non_terminated_nodes()` will refresh the states of `self.cached_nodes` and then ray will be able to detect whether the VM is terminated during ssh retry.

title: Fix Ray autoscaler's failure of gpu auto detection
body:
This PR aims to fix https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/836 which has been a recurring issue to me (happened three times).
This fix is done by checking the #gpu by nvidia-smi and set it manually in `ray start` rather than relying on Ray autoscaler auto-detection.
I tested this PR with running some spot VMs on GCP and they have been through several preemptions. so far the issue seems to be fixed.
But this is a hard-to-reproduce problem. I will try to launch 10 gpu VMs with and without this PR to see if there's difference.

Not sure if we should apply this change to other cloud templates.
